title: What Is a Content Strategy?
description: This is a complete guide to developing a content strategy. Topics covered include: topic research, content promotion and reporting.
content: Content StrategyWritten by Brian DeanLast updated Sep. 22, 2023What Is a Content Strategy? A content strategy (also known as ‚Äúcontent marketing strategy‚Äù) is an organization‚Äôs high-level approach for creating and marketing content. A strategy for creating content includes topic selection, content formats, writing style, design and promotion. Why Is a Content Strategy Important? Having a content strategy is important because it helps you plan your site‚Äôs content marketing. Without a strategy, many people jump from one tactic to another. One week they write blog posts. The next week they film some YouTube videos. But with a complete strategy laid out, you can create a detailed plan to execute on. (That‚Äôs not to say that your strategy should be set in stone. You can, and should, modify your strategy based on what‚Äôs working for you.) How to Develop a Content Strategy Find Audience-Focused Content Topics A common content marketing mistake is jumping into content creation right away. Pro content marketers know that finding the right topics is in many ways MORE important than the content itself. Specifically, you want to focus on topics that your target audience is SUPER interested in. Here‚Äôs how: Competitor Blogs Head over to a popular blog in your industry. And look for posts that tend to get lots of comments and social shares. For example, a while back I looked at what was content performed best on the Moz blog: And I noticed that content about ‚Äúsite audits‚Äù tended to do REALLY well: So I created a blog post called: ‚ÄúThe 15-Step SEO Audit Checklist‚Äù. Because this post was based on a proven topic, it was a huge hit on day 1. And quickly cracked the first page for my target keyword: Pro Tip: If one of your competitors has a podcast, check out their episode list on iTunes: This can reveal some killer topics that you‚Äôd be hard-pressed to find any other way. Online Communities Online communities are GREAT for finding burning questions that your customers have. For example, when I head over to the Paleo subreddit, I notice lots of questions about dessert: Why is this important? Most people ask questions on Reddit because they couldn‚Äôt find their answer on Google. This means there‚Äôs a HUGE opportunity for you to swoop in and answer that question with your content. You can follow this same process using Quora: If you want to scale this process, check out Answer the Public. It‚Äôs a free tool that hands you popular questions that people have around your topic: Pro Tip: Check out conference agendas in your industry. People are literally paying (and traveling) to see these talks. So you KNOW these topics are in high demand. Your Best Content Here‚Äôs where you double down on what works. First, login to Google Analytics and go to ‚ÄúBehavior‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúSite Content‚Äù ‚Üí ‚ÄúLanding Pages‚Äù: This shows you which pages on your site bring in the most traffic. Then, identify what those pages have in common in terms of: Format Topics Author Writing style Finally, outline your next piece of content based on what you find. For example: Last year I noticed that definitive guides brought in a ton of traffic. So I decided to publish more definitive guides as content pillars. And those new guides helped increase my blog‚Äôs traffic by 87.91% compared to the year before: Which leads us to‚Ä¶ Choose a Content Structure and Format In other words, here‚Äôs where you decide if you‚Äôre going to create a: Blog post YouTube Video Native video (for Facebook, LinkedIn, or Twitter) Lead magnet Ebook Infographic Case study Podcast Interactive content The key here is to choose the type of content that works best for YOU. Are you an awesome writer? Go with a blog post. Do you shine on video? Make a video. Or maybe you‚Äôre an amazing designer. Whip up a piece of visual content. I think you get the idea üôÇ In fact: You can cover the same topic using multiple different formats. Which can 5-10x the amount of usable content you can create around a single topic. For example, a few years ago I published this guide to building backlinks: Which did GREAT. So I made a YouTube video on that same exact topic: And it racked up 278,532 views: The big takeaway? There‚Äôs no ‚Äúperfect‚Äù content format for any topic. So as long as you choose a format that plays to your strengths, you‚Äôre good to go. Focus On Creating Amazing Content It‚Äôs harder than ever to for your content to stand out. According to WordPress, there are 2.49 million blog posts published every day: Plus, though content supply is increasing, content demand is flat. In fact, WordPress reports that pageviews are down again after a short pandemic-induced spike in 2020: Bottom Line? If you want to succeed with content marketing today, your content needs to be AMAZING. Here are a few tips to help you create amazing content. Professional Design There‚Äôs no way around this: If you want people to read and share your content, it needs to look GREAT. This is why I go the extra mile to use high-res screenshots: Visuals: And custom-designed guides: Real Life Examples When it comes to content, there‚Äôs one thing I‚Äôve found to be true almost 100% of the time: People LOVE examples. When you hear the words ‚Äúfor example‚Äù your brain breathes a sigh of relief. That‚Äôs because research shows that examples make learning easier. That‚Äôs why I include TONS of examples in every post: Does adding examples take more work than simply saying, ‚Äúdo this‚Äù? Sure. Is it worth it? Definitely. Written By an Expert In other words: Publish content from people who have actually done the things they‚Äôre writing about. Or as I like to say: ‚ÄúIf you want an article about how to unclog a toilet, don‚Äôt hire a freelance writer. Hire a plumber.‚Äù For example, Nerd Fitness quickly grew to be one of the most popular blogs in the fitness space. How? Steve wrote about his personal experience of trying different diets and workout routines: And he filled in any gaps in his knowledge with research from nutrition experts: Content UX When most people think ‚ÄúUX‚Äù, they think ‚ÄúSoftware‚Äù. But content has a user experience too. For example, look at this post: The text is all squished together. Which makes it REALLY hard to read. That‚Äôs bad Content UX. On the other hand, this post uses a big font with lots of white space: Which makes it easy to read and skim. That‚Äôs good Content UX. And Content UX isn‚Äôt just for text content. If you have a podcast, good UX is clear audio. If you‚Äôre making a video, good UX is that video‚Äôs production value. In short: Make it EASY for people to consume your content‚Ä¶ and it will perform MUCH better. Optimize Your Content for Search Engines Next, it‚Äôs time to optimize your content around a keyword. Specifically, you want to nail the basics of on-page SEO: Include your keyword in your title tag Optimize your title tag for CTR Use short URLs Add internal links to other pages on your site Use external links Format your content for readability Here‚Äôs a video that walks you through each of these steps in detail: Promote Your Content Promotion is a key part of any content strategy. The question is: how do you promote your content the right way? Here are a few simple strategies. Email Newsletters This is HUGE. An email list is the #1 content promotion tool on the planet. Period. In fact, there isn‚Äôt even a close second. Remember: Your subscribers are made up of people that LOVE your stuff. In other words: They‚Äôre people that are very likely to spread the word about your content. That‚Äôs why I share most of my posts with my email subscribers: As you can see, my email doesn‚Äôt look like a stuffy corporate newsletter. In fact, my email looks like it could be from a friend. This is EXACTLY how you want your emails to look. So, how did it do? That single email generated 14,067 total visitors: Nice! Content Roundups In case you‚Äôre not familiar with them, roundups are posts that curate (or ‚Äúroundup‚Äù) awesome content from the week. The best part? There are roundups in almost every niche. For example, this is a roundup from the wine niche: Here‚Äôs why promoting your content to link roundups works so well: Your pitch actually makes their life easier (yes, really). I‚Äôll explain‚Ä¶ Roundup curators struggle to find content to include in their roundup. And when you suggest your new post, you deliver awesome content on a silver platter. This means there‚Äôs no arm twisting required to get a link. For example, here‚Äôs a roundup that linked to me few years ago: This short video goes into the step-by-step process: Paid Content Promotion Specifically: Facebook Boosted Posts. I‚Äôve spent thousands on Facebook ads over the last few months. And the #1 lesson I learned is this: Retargeting is LEGIT. For example, a while ago, I recently boosted this Facebook post: And because I targeted people that recently visited Backlinko, I only paid 67 cents per click: Nice. Track and Measure Performance Now it‚Äôs time to see how well your content strategy is working. The question is: How do you know if your content ‚Äúworked‚Äù? Take a look at these key metrics: Traffic At the end of the day, the point of content marketing is to get more traffic. So if your content only brings in a handful of visitors, it‚Äôs time to switch things up. That said: Content marketing and SEO can take time to kick in. For example, look at the traffic numbers from the early days of Backlinko: As you can see, it took about 6 months for things to really take off. And if I gave up early on because content ‚Äúwasn‚Äôt working‚Äù, I wouldn‚Äôt have seen the huge traffic spike that got me going: Backlinks Sometimes you publish content for the sole purpose of getting backlinks. (In other words: linkbait.) For example, I published this voice search SEO study. My #1 goal with that post was to get more backlinks. So even though that post doesn‚Äôt bring in much traffic‚Ä¶ ‚Ä¶it‚Äôs been linked to 3,900 times to date: Including some heavy hitters (like Forbes): And these backlinks help boost my rankings for all of the other pages on my site. Speaking of rankings‚Ä¶ Google Rankings This is pretty straightforward: If you create content designed to rank for a specific keyword, it should rank for that keyword. If it doesn‚Äôt, then something‚Äôs off. It could be that the keyword is too competitive. Or it might be that you don‚Äôt have enough links. Either way, I recommend checking your rankings once a week. Social Shares In some niches (especially in B2C), content is sized up based on how many people share it on social media. Conversions ROI. Business goals. KPIs. Whatever you want to call it. Basically, you‚Äôre answering the question: Is content helping us get more sales? Now: You can directly measure conversions in Google Analytics: And if you see conversions moving up, it‚Äôs probably a sign that your content marketing is working. So you want to add more of that content type in your editorial calendar. That said: It‚Äôs sometimes hard to track content‚Äôs indirect sales impact. For example: My conversions that come directly from YouTube are super low: And if I ONLY looked at Google Analytics, I‚Äôd probably say: ‚ÄúYouTube is a waste of time‚Äù. But when I dig a little bit deeper, I can see that my YouTube channel is a HUGE driver of subscribers and sales. First of all, according to YouTube Studio, my videos reach 142,000 people every year: Do you think all of those views help my bottom line? Of course. But more important than that: customers cite my YouTube channel as the main reason that they decide to make a purchase: Which tells me that my YouTube content is paying off.
